page.title: 16FRISKNEY REMEMBERED
page.content: The changes in farm work are almost beyond belief since I began my working life 70 years ago. Nearly all farm workers lived in tied cottage and they walked to work or cycled if they were lucky. I was a wagonner and started work at 4.30 to have the horses ready by 6.30 and finished at 4 p.m. in the winter or 8 p.m. or later in the summer. Nearly all the work was of a manual nature. Potatoes were planted and picked by hand and put into 8 stone sacks and taken to Eastville station by horse or lorry. Cereals were drilled using horses, harvested using binders, dryed in stooks, stacked in the farmyard and later threshed and put into 12 to 18 stone bags which were carried manually. Weeds and pests were controlled by hand hoeing.There were many more small farms instead of todays large farms.
